Absolutely gorgeous â¤ğŸ‰
Yes, there's a concept of a makeup color wheel! It's based on the traditional color wheel used in art, but adapted to help with makeup choices. Here's how it works:  * Primary Colors: Red, yellow, and blue are the foundation.  * Secondary Colors: Mixing two primary colors creates secondary colors: green (blue + yellow), orange (red + yellow), and purple (red + blue).  * Tertiary Colors: Mixing a primary color with a neighboring secondary color creates tertiary colors. How it applies to makeup:  * Complementary Colors: Colors opposite each other on the wheel (like blue and orange) create high contrast and can make features pop.  * Analogous Colors: Colors next to each other on the wheel (like blue, blue-green, and green) create a harmonious and subtle look.  * Triadic Colors: Colors evenly spaced around the wheel (like red, yellow, and blue) create a vibrant and playful look. Using the Makeup Color Wheel:  * Eyeshadow: Choose eyeshadow shades that complement your eye color. For example, if you have blue eyes, orange and brown shades can make them pop.  * Blush: Select blush colors that mimic a natural flush. Consider your skin tone â€“ cooler tones might prefer pink blushes, while warmer tones might look better with peach or coral.  * Lipstick: Experiment with colors that complement your skin tone and the rest of your makeup. Keep in mind:  * Skin Tone: The makeup color wheel is a guide, but it's essential to consider your skin tone (cool, warm, or neutral) when choosing colors.  * Personal Preference: Ultimately, the best colors are the ones you feel confident and beautiful in! Let me know if you'd like more specific advice on using the makeup color wheel for your eye color or skin tone!

My question is, why do you continue to sell your products at Sophora's? My daughter and I was racially descriminated/profiled against by associates, I guess they were told to treat people of color a certain way. It's like they do not want people of color to shop there. Sorry, but the humiliation is not worth it and we will not be shopping at Sophora's ever again.

QUEEN
I seen this video early. ğŸ˜‚ I love RihannağŸ˜ğŸ˜˜ğŸ’–
I became a cosmetic buyer back in 1972 through the owner of a large drug store. First he had me compete with 2 other girls for a pharmacy tech, to see who could count the fastest, pour the fastest, compound creams, answer none stop phone, weigh on customers, fill out insurance papers, talk directly to Dr's, ect,ect back then no computers. So since every drug store has cosmetics, there were Representatives ( such as Revlon,LOreal ect) who came to talk to my boss and he nvr knew what to buy, so he needed a cosmetic buyer and since I wore make up, he asked me if I was willing to go to Revelon school of cosmetics for 2 weeks they would pay for it I said Yes. Went got my certificate and became cosmetic buyer for the drug store along with  also still being a pharmacy tech. Loved doing both jobs, I learned alot about medicine and cosmetics.  You hear Riri say she can put on her make up in 10 min? It's All True bc I did it too bc putting it on every day you just on autoplay. I use to tell everyone I could put my makeup blindfolded except the eyelashes. And the creams Riri talks about mixing I did the exact same thing but with lipsticks, i use to used brown eye shadow for my eyebrows, mixed different  hair colors to get a beautiful hair color,  So, being a cosmetic buyer I learned alot and had so much fun with it, Revlon and Loreal treated me wonderful. I got free cosmetics bc everything i bought for the store it sold  quickly. This is why I use to get alot of compliments. I would humbly help ladies with their makeup. Im sorry if I went on & on. But this is how I became a cosmetic buyer.
